If you are pumping iron, you need protein. Otherwise just from diet alone it can be quite challenging to get your protein intake. All things said, the following are what you need to keep in mind.
1. Get a high quality protein - preferably whey isolate and check for certification labels which ensure pure and tested protein content.
2. Consume only on your workout days and try to get your protein from food on your non workout days. Preferably consume before and after your workout.
3. Drink plenty of water.
4. If you are not working out say for a week, don't consume protein powder during that period.
5. Reduce your tea, coffee, soda intake. Puts less strain on your kidneys. Like I said, water is the best.
Like almost everything else in life, moderation and control is the key here. I have known people who aren't gym freaks or who consume protein powder, yet they have kidney issues. Watch what you eat and drink and you will be fine.

I liked this video among the least out of most ASAP Science videos because I find the thumbnail and video title misleading. The question they dive into isn't "How bad is protein powder?" (which is what I was actually wondering, how unhealthy it is to use in moderation) or even "How Much Protein Powder Will Kill You?" which is also an interesting, but different question. No, the subject of this video is, "What would happen if you eat EXCLUSIVELY PROTEIN POWDER AND NOTHING ELSE" which I find really misleading. Basically has very little to do with the toxicity of protein powder or how unhealthy it is to use in excess (along with other foods). I have a lot of respect for ASAP Science so it was disheartening to see them use such clickbait-y/"bait-n-switch" tactics like these. If the title was "What would happen to your body if you only ate protein powder?" then I would have no problem with the congruity of the video title and the subject matter.
